I booked my appointment and waited and waited and waited. No contact at all from the surgery, appalling. I wouldn't have a job if I treated my clients in this manner.

title: Inconsistent. Sometimes good sometime pretty…
body:
Like many, I have been a patient at Elizabeth Avenue since the early 2000s. 

During the past 20 years, there has been a general problem with the receptionists who could all do with regular refresher training in general civility. Yes, we are aware there is a pandemic and everyone (including patients) are working long, extra hours, so the receptionists may be under additional strain, but this does NOT excuse attitude, impatience and rudeness. It is simply unprofessional and counterproductive. It's NEVER OK or defensible. Manner (and manners) are important, as are receptiveness in a receptionist. It's a basic requirement of the role -- otherwise, get a job on a building site where such things matter less. 

The doctors and nursing staff are generally pleasant and accommodating and respond well to a bit of jollity and good tempered banter. I have managed to get jabs and referrals for key ailments over the years, but the Covid situation has seemingly rendered the surgery largely incapable of providing anything other than basic support. Despite 3-4 calls and conversations over the past year, I have yet to receive attention for a disorder which has seriously diminished my quality of life. The intervention of the same doctor over 6 months resulted in absolutely nothing, despite promises to the contrary. No follow-up calls or explanations have been received, so I guess I just have to continue to endure the problem or go privately, which is upsetting and disappointing.

I've always been a massive supporter of the NHS and greatly appreciative of medical care this country has to offer, but if this is the 'new normal', then I am glad to be in the autumn of my life. I feel certain the current government has no genuine desire to help support an institution which was founded by (and is inherently linked to) welfare state principles espoused by their political opposites. Headline £spending figures and glib 3-word slogans do not a healthcare policy make. Sad times ahead for Brexit Britain, and our medical services will suffer like everything else.

title: Same Day Emergency Care Unit
body: I was transferred to this unit from Cardiology, the receptionists were excellent, I was questioned at length by I know not who or his qualifications, he seemed very unsure and hesitant in what he was doing eventually after some hours I was given a prescription for medication there had been no examination or diagnoses the drug prescribed was not available at the hospital pharmacy so I had to return to the unit to have the prescription rewritten on to a green prescription this was written by a different person to the one who wrote the first one. I tried without success to obtain the drug from a number of chemists the following day in my area. I tried to contact the unit a number of times no one would answer the phone at all, I called the number on the prescription which was the UHL Parmacy Dept she informed me that the prescription had been badly filled out and I needed to contact them, in desperation I contacted PILs who were very helpful but also unable to contact the Unit eventually some seven hours later I managed to make contact with the person who issued the prescription who denied that the drug was unobtainable and advised me to contact my GP as he may be able to prescribe an alternative this was late on Friday afternoon so I could not contact my GP until Monday morning, despite being told by the hospital pharmacist I needed the drug on Thursday the day of issue. I contacted my GP on Monday to be told that this medication was only a trial (I was not informed of this at the time of issue) and advised me not to have it until further tests were carried out this is now being undertaken by my GP. My experience of my time in this Unit was that it appeared very unorganised apart from the ladies on the desk who were most helpful.

readBy.name: University Hospitals of Leicester NHS Trust

title: concerns re advice
body:
Contacted surgery yesterday morning, took an hour to get through...OK understandable
Receptionist requested information as to what the problem was so gave her relevant personal details   ....OK in this instance. 
Was told by receptionist to make a physio appt... unacceptable.
Did not expect or necessarily need an appt with GP but was not even offered a call back from GP to explain symptoms or concerns. Now the norm for GP's to diagnose over the phone but do not expect receptionist to diagnose! Very rarely need to consult a GP as my records will show. Very disappointed at the lack of care.

title: Excellent Care
body:
I was diagnosed with Stenosis and was advised to have an operation on my back.  I had my operation on Monday 2nd August 2021 which was extremely successful and I can't thank the Surgical and Nursing team enough for their care and attention and first class treatment.  Once again many thanks to you all

David Evans
